p:
To study the impact of early detection of pre-symptomatic individuals and isolation on the reproduction number, we first depict
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\mathscr {R}_c$$\end{document}
R c
as a function of
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$f_T$$\end{document}
f T
, for different levels of isolation effectiveness r. Figure 2 shows that the control reproduction number declines as the proportion,
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$f_T$$\end{document}
f T
, of pre-symptomatic individuals, who get diagnosed and isolated, increases. Simulations are done using parameter values from Table 2, but for three different values of r. It further shows that the curve corresponding to a low and an intermidate value of isolation effectivenes r (e.g.
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$r = 0.35$$\end{document}
r = 0.35
for the solid curve and
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$r = 0.65$$\end{document}
r = 0.65
for the dashed curve) hits
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\mathscr {R}_c = 1$$\end{document}
R c
= 1
at some critical value of
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$f_T$$\end{document}
f T
(say
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$f_T^{\star }$$\end{document}
f T ⋆
), while for the high value of r (
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$r = 0.95$$\end{document}
r = 0.95
), it never hits the critical threshold
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\mathscr {R}_c = 1$$\end{document}
R c
= 1
, as the curve is totally below the critical threshold. This indicates that for a high effectiveness of isolation, the control reproduction number is less than one and therefore the infection dies out. Analytically, the exact form of
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$f_T^{\star }$$\end{document}
f T ⋆
is
14
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\begin{aligned} f_T^{\star } = \left[ 1 + (1-r)\ell \frac{\alpha }{\gamma _r + \mu } - \frac{1}{\mathscr {R}_0} \left( 1 + \frac{\alpha }{\gamma +\mu }\right) \right] / \left[ 1 - \frac{(1-r)\ell (\gamma + \mu )}{\gamma _r + \mu } \right] . \end{aligned}$$\end{document}
f T ⋆
=

The critical proportion
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$f_T^{\star }$$\end{document}
f T ⋆
represents the minimum proportion of pre-symptomatic individuals who are detected and get isolated to ensure an effective control of Ebola. This critical value remains feasible as long as the following inequality holds
15
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\begin{aligned} (1-r)\ell < \frac{\gamma _r + \mu }{(\gamma + \mu )\mathscr {R}_0}. \end{aligned}$$\end{document}
( 1 - r )
ℓ <
γ r
+ μ
( γ + μ )
R 0
.
If we keep all parameters fixed except r, then condition ( 15) could be rewritten in a more convenient form
16
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\begin{aligned} r > 1- \frac{\gamma _r + \mu }{\ell (\gamma + \mu ) \mathscr {R}_0}. \end{aligned}$$\end{document}
r > 1 -
γ r
+ μ
ℓ
( γ + μ )
R 0
.
This gives the minimum level of effectiveness of isolation required to obtain an isolation and early diagnosis-based control strategy for Ebola tranmission.
